Shimla

Shimla is the capital of Himachal and a district that stretches from apple valleys to high ridges, carrying both colonial buildings and village life. Government offices run here, but so do apple mandis. Markets crowd the lanes, yet a short drive can take you to villages where time feels slower.

Our Hidden Favourites (Himachalites Recommended)

  • Shali Tibba Trek - The highest peak above Shimla. A $5–6\text{ km}$ walk from Khatnol through cedar forests. Go for sunrise. At the top, a small Bhimakali temple and a silence you’ll remember. Please don’t treat it like a picnic spot. Carry your waste back.
  • Cheog near Fagu - A quiet village with apple orchards, homestays, and even treehouses. A good stop if you want village life close to Shimla.
  • Tattapani - Natural hot water springs by the Sutlej. Locals believe they heal joint pains. River rafting is popular here too.
  • Bantony Castle - An old British estate right in Shimla town. Less talked about, but worth a visit if you want to see a quieter part of heritage.
  • Chadwick Falls - A short hike from Summer Hill. Best after rain when the fall is full. Go early in the morning to avoid crowds.

Towns & Villages

  • Shimla Town - The capital and the district HQ, featuring the Mall Road, Ridge, and historic buildings like Bantony Castle.
  • Mashobra - Known for old cottages, apple orchards, and the President's Retreat (Rashtrapati Niwas), which is often open to visitors.
  • Rampur (Rampur Bushahr) - Once a major trade seat on the Sutlej river.
  • Rohru - Market town situated by the Pabbar river, known as prime trout country.
  • Theog - Spread over five ridges, featuring a busy mandi (market) and a lively ground.
  • Jubbal - Palace town with strong roots in apple orchard farming.
  • Kotkhai - A key apple belt area, known for old fairs and traditional woodwork.
  • Chaupal (Chopal) - Forested hinterland region known for craft and seasonal fairs.
  • Kumarsain - Orchard town where the old palace is gone, but the valley is steady with fruit production.
  • Narkanda - Small hill town, famous for orchards in summer and skiing in winter.
  • Kufri - Famous for snow activities, including pony rides to Mahasu Peak and scenic views, especially in winter.
  • Naldehra - A quiet village located about $22–23\text{ km}$ from Shimla, known primarily for its old, picturesque golf course.
  • Cheog near Fagu - A small, calm village popular for homestays and offering a quiet, rural atmosphere close to Shimla.
  • Other Settlements - Shoghi, Junga, Nankhari, Nerwa, and Chirgaon are smaller towns and villages that maintain the traditional rural rhythm of the hills.
  • Sunni (Seoni) - Tehsil town located on a bend of the Sutlej river.

Culture & Festivals

  • Festivals & Fairs:
    • Summer Festival (May–June, Ridge Ground): Major event kicking off the tourist season with music, dance, crafts, and food stalls.
    • Sipi Fair (Mashobra, May): A local fair featuring folk performances and wrestling bouts.
    • Mahasu Jatar (Kotkhai belt, August): Community festival held at the Mahasu Devta temple, featuring village rituals and masked dances.
    • Ice Skating Carnival (Dec–Feb, Lakkar Bazaar): Linked with Asia’s oldest natural ice rink (when cold enough).
    • Lavi Trade Fair (Rampur, November): The biggest trading fair in the region, historically linked to old Bushahr–Tibet trade routes.
  • Theatre & Arts:
    • Gaiety Theatre: Located on the Ridge, it still stages plays, student productions, and film screenings. Many famous actors (e.g., Balraj Sahni, Anupam Kher) began their careers here.
    • Local youth groups also run small street plays in areas like Lower Bazaar and Sanjauli.
  • Folk Traditions:
    • Nati Dance: Performed at weddings and fairs, driven by dhol-damau drum beats, and remains part of daily village life.
    • Woodwork: Traditional Kath-kuni houses and wood carving traditions survive in areas like Kotkhai, Rohru, and Jubbal.
    • Local fairs in Jubbal and Rampur prominently feature Pahari shawls, woollen caps, and silver jewellery.
  • Youth Energy:
    • College students maintain the city's energy with inter-college fests, music nights, and trekking clubs.
    • Cafés in Sanjauli and Summer Hill often host cultural events like poetry readings, live guitars, and informal open mics.
    • NGOs and local students actively participate in community volunteering, including blood donation drives, clean-up walks, and drug awareness campaigns.

Education & Youth

  • Himachal Pradesh University (HPU) - Main state university in Summer Hill. It hosts an active cultural calendar and inter-college youth festivals annually.
  • HP National Law University (HPNLU) - Public law university in Shimla, known for regular academic lectures, foundation day events, and conferences.
  • Indira Gandhi Medical College (IGMC) - Top state medical college. It is highly ranked and regularly receives equipment upgrades from the state.
  • Govt. College Sanjauli - A recognized Centre of Excellence (NAAC A+), focusing on active placement/career workshops and co-curricular activities.
  • Atal Bihari Vajpayee Govt. Institute of Engineering & Technology (Pragatinagar) - The state engineering college for Shimla district.
  • Legacy Schools: Bishop Cotton School and Auckland House continue to be popular, drawing students from across India due to their strong legacy boarding and convent systems.

Our Stories

Exploring the majestic peaks of the Himalayas, capturing breathtaking moments.

Immersing ourselves in the rich culture and vibrant traditions of Himachal Pradesh.

Food & Markets

  • Markets Layered by Character:
    • Mall Road & The Ridge: The main promenade featuring cafés, bookshops, branded stores, and evening walks.
    • Upper Bazaar: Known for branded shops. Cheaper versions of goods are typically found in the lanes below.
    • Lower Bazaar: The place for local clothes, daily wear, street food, and old, established shops.
    • Ram Bazaar: The hub for everyday essentials, including the sabzi mandi (vegetable market), flower shops, and masala stalls.
    • Sanjauli: An expanding market area that includes some modern branded stores alongside local vendors.
  • Food We Trust (Local Eateries):
    • Cafe 1873: Tucked slightly off Mall Road, known for reliable food quality.
    • Cafe Simla Times: Known primarily for its good ambience and setting.
    • Himachali Rasoi (Lower Bazaar): The best spot for authentic, proper Himachali *Dham* (traditional feast).

Respect & Etiquette

  • General Approach: Please treat these spaces with respect, not as picnic spots. Walk softly; don’t impose yourself. Let the place reveal what it wants to show you.
  • Sacred Spaces & Dress Code:
    • Come clean: Avoid alcohol, meat/non-veg, and eggs before visiting temples.
    • Silence matters: Don’t blast music or turn temple surroundings into a picnic ground. Quiet is part of the experience.
    • Menstruation Note: In many villages, customs suggest women avoid visiting sacred sites during menstruation. This follows age-old traditions where the community sees these places as deeply charged.
  • Water Bodies: Stay away from streams, rivers, or ponds unless locals say it’s safe or respectful to enter. Never jump into sacred ponds or springs without permission, as some are reserved for rituals.
  • Local Guidance & Safety: Ask before you enter or participate; local guidance will help you avoid mistakes and keep you safe.
  • Environmental Responsibility:
    • Don’t litter: Carry back everything you bring. Please don’t leave chip packets, bottles, diapers, pads, or plastics behind.
    • Leave lighter than you arrived: Your respect keeps the mountains alive for those who come after you.
